title.narrative: ACCESS TO QUALITY EDUCATION

description.narrative: Access to quality education - More children, especially girls, access and complete quality education in safe and conducive school environment (grades 1 -9) , which contributes to Equitable Access To Quality Education, Learning Outcomes, Skills Development. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Evaluations, Research And Data, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2019, the most vulnerable boys and girls will have access to quality education, with a focus on improving learning outcomes

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Access to quality education - More children, especially girls, access and complete quality education in safe and conducive schoolenvironment (grades 1 -9);

description.narrative: In 2019, more than 15,963 students (including 7,086 girls) in 10 schools in the provinces of Bie and Moxico benefited from expanded access through improved water and sanitation facilities and knowledge on positive WASH practices. In Huila, literacy and accelerated learning programmes reestablished the right to quality education for 2,752 (1,278 girls) children in primary education and 234 (198 girls and women) adolescents and adults. UNICEF Angola also directly supported more than 4,580 primary school children with education in emergency interventions. | Status:Met | As-of Date:03/07/2019

title.narrative: National education system implementing a minimum package of interventions to promote inclusiveness and quality(63054)

actual.value: 2019:The MoE continued to implement the National Inclusive Education Strategy approved in 2017, including trainings on the policy and the establishment of Special Education Resource centres in 13 provinces.
